bibl.title: Letter from Joseph A. LePrince to William Crawford Gorgas, July 24, 1908 [Enclosed in KAGB0130]

div1.p: LePrince informs Gorgas of the efficiency of Phinotas Oil as a larvacide. [Courtesy of The Albert and Shirley Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia Library]

div1.head: Letter from Joseph A. LePrince to William Crawford Gorgas, July 24, 1908 [Enclosed in KAGB0130]
div1.opener:
Ancon, July 24, 1908
Colonel W. C. Gorgas
Chief Sanitary Officer, ANCON
CANAL ZONE GOVERNMENT
RECEIVED
✓ File. No. 1097-6-M
JUL 27 1908
CHIEF SANITARY OFFICE
ANCON. C. Z.
Dear Sir:
div1.p:
In reply to your request for information concerning the
efficiency of PHINOTAS OIL as a larvacide, I beg to submit the
following information :

The first sample of PHINOTAS oil sent to us was in every
respect satisfactory. Also the first consignment received
was as good as the sample. Since that time, however, there
has been a large amount of variation in the lots received.
There seem to be three (3) kinds.

1ST CLASS : Forms milky emulsion at once and diffuses
rapidly.

2ND CLASS : Goes straight to bottom (sinks) and forms
partial emulsion.
3RD CLASS : Stays on the surface like oil.

The 1st-class gives best satisfaction and kills larvae
at once.

The pools into which PHINOTAS is placed become breeding
places again a few days after the application unless the better
class of phinotas is used; i.e., a quality of phinotas equiva-
lent to the lot first shipped to us.

I would advise that Major Kean obtain a sample lot of
100 gallons. If that lot is satisfactory, then about two gal-
lons of it should be bottled and kept for making comparative
tests with other samples submitted, and he should retain the
right to refuse any lot not coming up to standard.
div1.closer:
Very respectfully, J. A. LePrince Chief Sanitary Inspector
(SD)
